hints.content:
### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2+4x+8y+16&=0\\\\
(x^2+4x)+(y^2+8y)+16&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2+4x)+(y^2+8y)&=-16&\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2+4x\purpleD{+4})+(y^2+8y)&=-16\purpleD{+4}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2+4x\purpleD{+4})+(y^2+8y\redE{+16})&=-16\purpleD{+4}\redE{+16}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x+2)^2+(y+4)^2&=4&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

options.explanation:
Suppose we have the expression $x^2+ax$ where $a$ is any constant number. Let's visualize a partial square with an area of $x^2+\dfrac{a}{2}x+\dfrac{a}{2}x$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9490079b0c37067b1f0789fa90d7ba4dddc0b922)

What would we need to add to complete the square?

If we add $\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}$ to the expression, we will be able to rewrite it as the perfect square $\left(x+\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2$, which is very useful for many purposes.

$\begin{align}
x^2+ax+\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}&=x^2+2\cdot\dfrac{a}{2}\cdot x+\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}\\\\
&=\left(x+\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2
\end{align}$

In our case, turning $x^2+ax$ or $y^2+ay$ into perfect squares helps us in bringing the equation to standard form.

Just remember that whatever constant we add to one side of the equation, we need to add it to the other side too!

hints.content:
### Finding the center and the radius

This is the equation written in standard form:

$(x-(\blueE{-2}))^2+(y-(\maroonD{-4}))^2=\goldE{2}^2$

Therefore, the center of our circle is at $(\blueE{-2},\maroonD{-4})$ and the radius is $\goldE{2}$.

### Graphing the circle

We graph the circle by dragging the center of the circle to $(\blueE{-2},\maroonD{-4})$ and then dragging the outline so the radius is $\goldE{2}$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6f667631de1a48b8b150e5027779ea59a51dd554)

### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 2]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2 +2x +4y -44&=0\\\\
(x^2 +2x)+(y^2 +4y) -44&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 +2x)+(y^2 +4y)&= 44 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 +2x\purpleD{+1})+(y^2 +4y)&=44\purpleD{+1}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 +2x\purpleD{+1})+(y^2 +4y\redE{+4})&=44\purpleD{+1}\redE{+4}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x +1)^2+(y +2)^2&=49&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

Therefore, the center of our circle is at $(\blueE{-1},\maroonD{-2})$ and the radius is $\goldE{7}$.

We graph the circle by dragging the center of the circle to $(\blueE{-1},\maroonD{-2})$ and then dragging the outline so the radius is $\goldE{7}$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9fb4413f4345ee8fd67af162b52ccafd75ebafe9)

### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 2]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2 +10x +6y +18&=0\\\\
(x^2 +10x)+(y^2 +6y) +18&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 +10x)+(y^2 +6y)&= -18 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 +10x\purpleD{+25})+(y^2 +6y)&=-18\purpleD{+25}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 +10x\purpleD{+25})+(y^2 +6y\redE{+9})&=-18\purpleD{+25}\redE{+9}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x +5)^2+(y +3)^2&=16&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/db4d47db9955052b6277d134fb366e6b012f17fb)

### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 2]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2 -14x +2y +41&=0\\\\
(x^2 -14x)+(y^2 +2y) +41&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -14x)+(y^2 +2y)&= -41 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 -14x\purpleD{+49})+(y^2 +2y)&=-41\purpleD{+49}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -14x\purpleD{+49})+(y^2 +2y\redE{+1})&=-41\purpleD{+49}\redE{+1}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x -7)^2+(y +1)^2&=9&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 2]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2 -12x +6y +36&=0\\\\
(x^2 -12x)+(y^2 +6y) +36&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -12x)+(y^2 +6y)&= -36 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 -12x\purpleD{+36})+(y^2 +6y)&=-36\purpleD{+36}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -12x\purpleD{+36})+(y^2 +6y\redE{+9})&=-36\purpleD{+36}\redE{+9}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x -6)^2+(y +3)^2&=9&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/03e8ff1a475ca2807776adc6c4aae58bf25ce2f3)

### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 2]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2 -4x +8y -5&=0\\\\
(x^2 -4x)+(y^2 +8y) -5&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -4x)+(y^2 +8y)&= 5 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 -4x\purpleD{+4})+(y^2 +8y)&=5\purpleD{+4}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -4x\purpleD{+4})+(y^2 +8y\redE{+16})&=5\purpleD{+4}\redE{+16}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x -2)^2+(y +4)^2&=25&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 2]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2 +6x -10y +18&=0\\\\
(x^2 +6x)+(y^2 -10y) +18&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 +6x)+(y^2 -10y)&= -18 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 +6x\purpleD{+9})+(y^2 -10y)&=-18\purpleD{+9}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 +6x\purpleD{+9})+(y^2 -10y\redE{+25})&=-18\purpleD{+9}\redE{+25}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x +3)^2+(y -5)^2&=16&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 3]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2 +16x -16y +124&=0\\\\
(x^2 +16x)+(y^2 -16y) +124&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 +16x)+(y^2 -16y)&= -124 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 +16x\purpleD{+64})+(y^2 -16y)&=-124\purpleD{+64}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 +16x\purpleD{+64})+(y^2 -16y\redE{+64})&=-124\purpleD{+64}\redE{+64}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x +8)^2+(y -8)^2&=4&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

(x^2 +8x)+(y^2 -2y) -19&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 +8x)+(y^2 -2y)&= 19 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 +8x\purpleD{+16})+(y^2 -2y)&=19\purpleD{+16}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 +8x\purpleD{+16})+(y^2 -2y\redE{+1})&=19\purpleD{+16}\redE{+1}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x +4)^2+(y -1)^2&=36&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

options.explanation:
Suppose we have the expression $x^2+ax$ where $a$ is any constant number. Let's visualize a partial square with an area of $x^2+\dfrac{a}{2}x+\dfrac{a}{2}x$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9490079b0c37067b1f0789fa90d7ba4dddc0b922)

What would we need to add to complete the square?

If we add $\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}$ to the expression, we will be able to rewrite it as the perfect square $\left(x+\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2$, which is very useful for many purposes.

$\begin{align}
x^2+ax+\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}&=x^2+2\cdot\dfrac{a}{2}\cdot x+\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}\\\\
&=\left(x+\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2
\end{align}$

In our case, turning $x^2+ax$ or $y^2+ay$ into perfect squares helps us in bringing the equation to standard form.

Just remember that whatever constant we add to one side of the equation, we need to add it to the other side too!

hints.content:
### Finding the center and the radius

This is the equation written in standard form:

$(x-(\blueE{-4}))^2+(y-\maroonD{1})^2=\goldE{6}^2$

Therefore, the center of our circle is at $(\blueE{-4},\maroonD{1})$ and the radius is $\goldE{6}$.

### Graphing the circle

We graph the circle by dragging the center of the circle to $(\blueE{-4},\maroonD{1})$ and then dragging the outline so the radius is $\goldE{6}$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3062721f8ad317d43b0727bd7a680ecbe21ed017)

### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 2]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2 -10x -10y +25&=0\\\\
(x^2 -10x)+(y^2 -10y) +25&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -10x)+(y^2 -10y)&= -25 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 -10x\purpleD{+25})+(y^2 -10y)&=-25\purpleD{+25}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -10x\purpleD{+25})+(y^2 -10y\redE{+25})&=-25\purpleD{+25}\redE{+25}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x -5)^2+(y -5)^2&=25&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 2]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2 -4x -10y +20&=0\\\\
(x^2 -4x)+(y^2 -10y) +20&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -4x)+(y^2 -10y)&= -20 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 -4x\purpleD{+4})+(y^2 -10y)&=-20\purpleD{+4}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -4x\purpleD{+4})+(y^2 -10y\redE{+25})&=-20\purpleD{+4}\redE{+25}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x -2)^2+(y -5)^2&=9&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 2]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2 -14x -12y +76&=0\\\\
(x^2 -14x)+(y^2 -12y) +76&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -14x)+(y^2 -12y)&= -76 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 -14x\purpleD{+49})+(y^2 -12y)&=-76\purpleD{+49}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -14x\purpleD{+49})+(y^2 -12y\redE{+36})&=-76\purpleD{+49}\redE{+36}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x -7)^2+(y -6)^2&=9&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

What would we need to add to complete the square?

If we add $\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}$ to the expression, we will be able to rewrite it as the perfect square $\left(x+\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2$, which is very useful for many purposes.

$\begin{align}
x^2+ax+\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}&=x^2+2\cdot\dfrac{a}{2}\cdot x+\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}\\\\
&=\left(x+\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2
\end{align}$

In our case, turning $x^2+ax$ or $y^2+ay$ into perfect squares helps us in bringing the equation to standard form.

Just remember that whatever constant we add to one side of the equation, we need to add it to the other side too!

### Finding the center and the radius

This is the equation written in standard form:

$(x-\blueE{7})^2+(y-\maroonD{6})^2=\goldE{3}^2$

Therefore, the center of our circle is at $(\blueE{7},\maroonD{6})$ and the radius is $\goldE{3}$.

### Graphing the circle

We graph the circle by dragging the center of the circle to $(\blueE{7},\maroonD{6})$ and then dragging the outline so the radius is $\goldE{3}$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/91dc4eab1c8b70a4c8153e142c89933620c5eec4)

### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 2]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2 -2x  -80&=0\\\\
(x^2 -2x)+(y^2 ) -80&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 -2x)+(y^2 )&= 80 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
(x^2 -2x\purpleD{+1})+(y^2 )&=80\purpleD{+1}&\text{Complete the square for the x-terms.}\\\\
&&y^2\text{ is already a perfect square.}\\\\
(x -1)^2+(y )^2&=81&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$

options.explanation:
Suppose we have the expression $x^2+ax$ where $a$ is any constant number. Let's visualize a partial square with an area of $x^2+\dfrac{a}{2}x+\dfrac{a}{2}x$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9490079b0c37067b1f0789fa90d7ba4dddc0b922)

What would we need to add to complete the square?

If we add $\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}$ to the expression, we will be able to rewrite it as the perfect square $\left(x+\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2$, which is very useful for many purposes.

$\begin{align}
x^2+ax+\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}&=x^2+2\cdot\dfrac{a}{2}\cdot x+\tealE{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2}\\\\
&=\left(x+\dfrac{a}{2}\right)^2
\end{align}$

In our case, turning $x^2+ax$ or $y^2+ay$ into perfect squares helps us in bringing the equation to standard form.

Just remember that whatever constant we add to one side of the equation, we need to add it to the other side too!

hints.content:
### Finding the center and the radius

This is the equation written in standard form:

$(x-\blueE{1})^2+(y-\maroonD{0})^2=\goldE{9}^2$

Therefore, the center of our circle is at $(\blueE{1},\maroonD{0})$ and the radius is $\goldE{9}$.

### Graphing the circle

We graph the circle by dragging the center of the circle to $(\blueE{1},\maroonD{0})$ and then dragging the outline so the radius is $\goldE{9}$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9ea2a6d6638bd17cca0af27801dff3c360d67499)

### The standard circle equation

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Completing the squares

We will bring the equation to standard form by using the method of completing the square. [[☃ explanation 2]]

$\begin{align}
x^2+y^2  +4y -60&=0\\\\
(x^2 )+(y^2 +4y) -60&=0&\text{Group x-terms and y-terms.}\\\\
(x^2 )+(y^2 +4y)&= 60 &\text{Isolate constant term.}\\\\
&&x^2\text{ is already a perfect square.}\\\\
(x^2 )+(y^2 +4y\redE{+4})&=60\redE{+4}&\text{Complete the square for the y-terms.}\\\\
(x )^2+(y +2)^2&=64&\text{Factor perfect squares and simplify.}
\end{align}$
